Graphical abstract This paper focuses on the identification of cobalt and iron species in bimetallic alumina supported catalysts and their role in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The catalysts are prepared via aqueous coimpregnation of alumina with solutions of cobalt and iron nitrates followed by calcination in air and reduction in hydrogen. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of cobalt and iron phases were performed using XANES/EXAFS, XRD, TPR, XPS and magnetic method. The results show that Co3O4 and Fe2O3 are the major phases in the calcined monometallic cobalt and iron catalysts, while the bimetallic catalysts also exhibited the presence of mixed Co–Fe oxides. Reduction of these Co–Fe oxides leads to cobalt–iron bimetallic particles. The Fischer–Tropsch reaction rate increases with cobalt content in bimetallic catalysts. Formation of mixed cobalt–iron species increases selectivity to lighter olefins compared to cobalt monometallic catalyst but leads to lower Fischer–Tropsch reaction rates. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Biosyngas Bimetallic catalysts Cobalt catalyst Iron catalyst 1 Introduction Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FT) produces clean fuels from syngas (mixture of CO, H2) [1–5]. The syngas can be manufactured from fossil and renewable feedstocks (natural gas, coal and biomass). The synthetic fuels obtained using FT synthesis have a high cetane number and do not contain sulfur or aromatics. They could be considered therefore as a real alternative to traditional fuels from crude oil. The contribution of renewable resources such as biomass to the global energy supply has been growing in recent years [3]. Cobalt catalysts are the catalysts of choice for synthesis of long-chain hydrocarbons via low temperature FT synthesis from syngas. Long-chain hydrocarbons generally are produced on cobalt catalysts supported on oxide supports such as alumina, silica or carbon materials [5–8]. It is known that the catalytic conversion of carbon monoxide occurs on the cobalt metal sites and that FT reaction rate is a function of cobalt dispersion, reducibility and stability. Iron catalysts which are much cheaper are also used commercially for low temperature FT synthesis, however with somewhat lower activity than cobalt catalysts. In this context, cobalt–iron bimetallic catalysts with optimized catalytic performance seem to be a viable option for converting syngas into hydrocarbons [9–13]. In addition, iron species in bimetallic catalysts which may have a significant activity in the water gas shift (WGS) reaction [1] could be used to adjust H2/CO ratio in syngas and thus, make the FT technology more flexible to different types of feedstock. Previously cobalt–iron mixed catalysts have been a subject of several investigations. The obtained results were however rather contradictory. De la Pena O'Shea et al. [14] observed lower activity of silica supported cobalt monometallic catalysts in fixed bed reactor compared to iron counterparts. The activity of cobalt and iron catalyst supported on HMS mesoporous materials was studied by Bragana et al. [15]. HMS supported Co–Fe catalyst showed the highest activity and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivity, while Co-Fe/SBA-15 catalyst revealed highest selectivity to alcohols. Mixed cobalt–iron particles supported on carbon nanotubes were studied by Tavasoli et al. [16]. The monometallic cobalt catalyst exhibited high selectivity (85.1%) toward C5+ liquid hydrocarbons, while addition of small amounts of iron did not significantly affect the product selectivity. Lögdberg et al. [9] found that alloys of cobalt with small amount of iron improved the FT activity compared to the monometallic iron catalyst. The present work focuses on the identification of different cobalt and iron phases present on the alumina supported catalysts with different Co/Fe ratio during catalyst preparation and activation using a combination of techniques: nitrogen adsorption, ex situ and in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray absorption (XANES/EXAFS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), in situ magnetization measurements and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Particular attention is paid to interaction between cobalt and iron species in bimetallic catalysts at different catalysts preparation stages. The catalytic performance in FT synthesis has been evaluated in a Flowrence high-throughput unit (Avantium). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The monometallic cobalt or iron catalysts were synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation of alumina (Puralox SCCA 5/170 Sasol, S BET =183m2/g, pore diameter=8nm) using aqueous solutions of cobalt or iron nitrates obtained from the following precursors: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Fluka) and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Fluka). The cobalt or iron content in the monometallic catalysts prepared in a single impregnation step was 10wt.%. The bimetallic catalysts were synthesized via one step incipient wetness (co)impregnation of the alumina support. The total content of metals in the catalysts was 10wt.%. The prepared solids have the following weight compositions: xCoyFe/Al2O3, with x and y =0, 2.5wt.%, 5wt.%, 7.5wt.%, 10wt.% and x + y =10wt.%. The impregnated catalysts were dried at 383K for 12h and calcined at 673K for 5h (1°C/min) in a flow of air. After calcination, the samples were sieved to remove catalyst particles smaller than 50μm and larger than 150μm, then reduced in situ in fixed bed reactor in hydrogen at 673K for 12h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization At different stages of the preparation, the catalysts have been characterized by a wide range of ex situ and in situ techniques. The metal content in the catalysts was measured by X-ray fluorescence at the “Service Central d’Analyse du CNRS” (Vernaison, France). The elementary analysis data are in good agreement with the theoretical values (Table 1 ). The BET surface area and pore size distribution were measured using nitrogen adsorption at 77K. Prior to the experiments, the samples were outgassed at 423K for 5h. The isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 system. The total pore volume (TPV) was calculated from the amount of vapor adsorbed at a relative pressure close to unity assuming that the pores are filled with the condensate in the liquid state. The pore size distribution curves were calculated from the desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) formula [17]. Ex situ X-ray powder diffraction experiments were conducted using a Bruker AXS D8 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.1538nm) for crystalline phase detection. The XRD patterns were collected in 20–70° (2θ) range at 1.2°/min. The identification was carried out by comparison with JCPDF standard spectra software. The average crystallite size of Co3O4 (Table 1) was calculated using the 511 (2θ =59.5°) diffraction lines according to the Scherrer equation [18]. The in situ time-resolved XRD data of 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst were measured at the BM01B-SNBL beamline (ESRF, France) using a high resolution diffractometer, a gas manifold system and a capillary cell reactor. The setup was described previously [19,20]. The known amount of catalyst was loaded in the quartz capillary (m =12.3mg, OD=2mm) and pressed from both sides with quartz wool. The capillary was attached to the stainless steel holder using high temperature epoxy glue. A Cyberstar gas blower was used to control the capillary reactor temperature. The total pressure in the reactor (up to 20bar) was regulated by a back pressure controller. The gas lines before and after the reactor were heated up to 493K using Horst heating tape to prevent condensation of liquid products. Before the FT tests the catalysts were reduced in hydrogen flow at 658K at atmospheric pressure (temperature ramp of 3K/min) and cooled down to 333K in H2 flow. After the reduction, the catalyst was cooled down to 433K and exposed to the syngas (H2/CO=2) at atmospheric pressure. Then the reactors were pressurized up to 20bar and temperature of the catalyst was risen up to 506K with ramping rate of 1K/min. The time-resolved XRD patterns were recorded in situ under gas flows first at 20bar, H2/CO=2, GHSV=25,000cm3 g−1 h−1 for 145min, then at 20bar H2/CO=1, GHSV=17,500cm3 g−1 h−1 for additional 278min. The measuring time per a XRD pattern in the 2θ range between 5° and 35° was close to 20min. XAS spectra at Co K-edge (7.709keV) or/and Fe K-edge (7.112keV) were acquired at the BM01B-SNBL beamline (ESRF, France) using a Si (111) double crystal monochromator in transmission mode. Crystalline Co3O4, CoO, Co foil, Fe3O4, and Fe2O3 were used as reference compounds for XANES and EXAFS analysis. The data analysis was performed applying the IFFEFIT software. The EXAFS oscillations were extracted using the program Athena. The XANES spectra after background correction were normalized by the edge height. The Co K-edge EXAFS was analyzed using the standard data analysis procedure. The EXAFS signal was then transformed without phase correction from k space to r space (k3, Hanning window, 0–12Å−1) to obtain the radial distribution function (RDF). The reducibility of the catalysts was studied by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) using an AutoChem II 2920 apparatus (Micromeritics), 0.2g of the sample was treated by a 5vol% H2/Ar stream with a gas flow velocity of 30cm3/min. The temperature was increased from room temperature to 1273K at a rate of 2.5K/min. In situ magnetic measurements were performed using a Foner vibrating-sample magnetometer as described previously [21]. The design of the magnetometer allows recording curves of magnetization during temperature-programmed heating or under isothermal conditions at 290–873K. Temperature-programmed reduction experiments were carried out in pure hydrogen. The sample amount was about 30mg in all experiments. The gas flow velocity was 60mL/min and the rate of temperature ramping was 12K/min. The appearance of cobalt metallic species, Fe3O4 and iron metallic species in the catalysts was monitored in situ by a continuous increase in sample magnetization during the reduction. Surface analyses were performed using a VG ESCALAB 220XL X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS). The Al kα non-monochromatized line (1486.6eV) was used for excitation with a 300W-applied power. The analyzer was operated in a constant pass energy mode (E pass =40eV). The binding energies were referenced respectively to the Al2p core level (74.6eV) of the Al2O3 support. In situ reduction was carried out in pure hydrogen at 673K for 5h in the reactor cell of the spectrometer preparation chamber; the preparation and analysis chamber were linked hermetically. The sample was transferred from the preparation to the analysis chamber under vacuum without exposure to air. Special attention was required for the estimate of surface atomic Co/Al and Fe/Al ratios after the subtraction of the Auger contributions from Fe and Co respectively. The decomposition allowed estimating the percentages of the different species in the calcined and reduced catalysts. The particle sizes of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 in the calcined catalysts were estimated with the Kerkhof–Moulijn model [22]. The cobalt or iron dispersions were calculated for the oxidized catalysts from the XPS n (Co or Fe)/n Al ratio respectively divided by the n (Co or Fe)/n Al ratio corresponding to monolayer coverage. 2.3 Catalytic measurements Carbon monoxide hydrogenation was carried out in a Flowrence high throughput unit [23] equipped with 16 parallel milli-fixed reactors (d int =2mm) operating at a total pressure of 20bar, H2/CO=2molar ratio and GHSV=6700cm3/gh. The catalyst loading was 50mg. Prior to the catalytic test, all the samples were activated in a flow of pure hydrogen at atmospheric pressure during 10h at 673K with at GHSV=2NLh−1 g−1. During the reduction, the temperature ramp was 3K/min. After the reduction, the catalysts were cooled down to 433K and a flow of premixed syngas was gradually introduced through the catalysts. When pressure attained 20bar, the temperature was slowly increased to 493K. Gaseous reaction products were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography. Analysis of permanent gases was performed using a Molecular Sieve column and a thermal conductivity detector. Carbon dioxide and C1–C4 hydrocarbons were separated in a PPQ column and analyzed by a thermoconductivity detector. C5–C12 hydrocarbons were analyzed using CP-Sil5 column and a flame-ionization detector. The carbon monoxide contained 5% of helium, which was used as an internal standard for calculating carbon monoxide conversion. Catalytic rates and selectivities were measured at the steady-state regime after 48h time-on-stream. The reaction rates expressed in molh−1 g−1, were defined as the number of moles of CO converted per hour per gram of catalyst. The product selectivity (S) was reported as the percentage of CO converted into a given product and is expressed in C atoms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calcined samples The XRD patterns of calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . In addition to γ-alumina, they confirm the presence of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 phases in the monometallic cobalt and iron catalysts. The mean size of Co3O4 crystallites in the monometallic catalysts was calculated using the Scherrer equation [18]. The size of Co3O4 crystallites was about 11nm in 10Co/Al2O (Table 1). The XRD peaks of Fe2O3 were too broad for the evaluation of crystallite sizes using the Scherrer equation. This suggests a high dispersion of iron on the support. For the bimetallic catalysts with cobalt content higher than 2.5wt.%, the XRD peaks also confirm the presence of Co3O4 crystalline phase (Fig. 1). Very broad Fe2O3 peaks observed in the bimetallic alumina supported catalysts suggest high iron dispersion. Low intensity and significant peak broadening especially for iron crystallites make it difficult to systematically calculate the sizes of iron and cobalt oxide crystallites from XRD patterns. The textural characteristics of the calcined catalysts are also shown in Table 1. Smaller pore volume and BET surface area are observed in the catalysts with larger cobalt fraction. This coincides with higher concentration of relatively large cobalt particles with a diameter close to the pore sizes and which may block some of the catalyst pores. The XANES spectra (Fig. 2 (A)d and (B)d) of monometallic 10Co/Al2O3, 10Fe/Al2O3 and reference compounds indicate respectively the presence of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 phases in the calcined monometallic catalysts. The XANES spectra at Co and Fe K-edges were fitted using a liner combination of reference compounds. The results of XANES fits are presented in Table 2 as relative fractions of these reference compounds. The quality of the fits is evaluated using R-factor (coefficient of determination). Addition of aluminates to the fit did not improve the fit quality. For better comparison with XPS data, the fractions of Co3+, Co2+, Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions calculated from XANES data are also displayed in Table 4. The decomposition of XANES spectra of 10Co/Al2O3 and 10Fe/Al2O3 shows that the relative fractions of Co3+ and Co2+ are respectively equal to 67 and 33% as in the stoichiometric Co3O4 and the fraction of Fe3+ is around 100% as in Fe2O3 (Table 2). This suggests that Co3O4 and Fe2O3 are dominant metal phases in the monometallic 10Co/Al2O3 and 10Fe/Al2O3 catalysts. The iron K-edge XANES spectra of the bimetallic catalysts except for 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 are characteristic of Fe3+ species (Fig. 2A). For 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 the XANES also suggests the presence of Fe2+ ions. The quantitative decomposition of XANES spectrum estimates the fraction of Fe2+ species close to 20% and the fraction of Fe3+ ions close to 80%. In bimetallic catalysts, the cobalt K-edge XANES spectra evolve with cobalt content (Fig. 2B); they suggest a higher fraction of Co2+ species in the catalysts with lower cobalt content. For 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst, the shape of cobalt K-edge XANES spectrum is characteristic of Co2+ ions. In the 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 sample, the fraction of Co2+ ions is higher than in Co3O4. This could be indicative of the presence of other cobalt phases in bimetallic catalysts in addition to Co3O4. Note that the K-absorption edges of iron (7112eV) and cobalt (7709eV) are very close. The EXAFS range at the iron K absorption edge (<500eV) seems to be insufficient for quantitative analysis. Thus, only EXAFS data for the cobalt absorption edge were analyzed in this work. For all catalysts with exception for 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3, the moduli of the EXAFS Fourier transform consist of several peaks characteristic of Co3O4 structure [24]. Co3O4 has a spinel structure with Co2+ ions occupying tetrahedral sites and Co3+ occupying octahedral sites. In agreement with previous reports [24], the broad peak at 1.47Å is attributed to CoO coordination shell for both Co2+ and Co3+ coordination shells. These two coordination shells are usually not resolved in Fourier transform moduli [25,26]. The overlapped peaks at 2.50 and 3.02Å are attributed to Co–Co coordination in Co3O4 (Fig. 3 ). More detailed information about the attribution of the peaks in the modulus of the Fourier transform of EXAFS of Co3O4 is available in our previous publications [24–26]. Different EXAFS data were obtained for the 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst with low cobalt content. The first peak is shifted at 1.44Å and the peaks of Co–Co coordination are situated at 2.39 and 2.94Å. This catalyst also showed an unusually higher concentration of Co2+ species estimated from XANES data. Thus in this catalyst, the both XANES and EXAFS data suggest formation of cobalt compounds different from Co3O4. The calcined catalysts were also measured using XPS. Examples of Co 2p and Fe 2p XPS spectra of bimetallic catalysts are given in Fig. 4 . The XPS Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 binding energies for monometallic 10Co/Al2O3 were respectively at 796.6 and 781.0eV (Table 3 ). This indicates [27–29] that Co3O4 is the dominant phase in this catalyst. For monometallic 10Fe/Al2O3 catalyst the Fe 2p3/2 binding energy at 711.6eV confirms [30–32] the predominance of the Fe2O3 phase. Co 2p XPS spectra are also consistent with the results obtained by X-ray absorption spectroscopies. Co 2p XPS spectra for 7.5Co2.5Fe/Al2O3 and 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 are very similar to the spectrum for the reference Co3O4 and cobalt monometallic catalyst with Co 2p3/2 binding energies at about 780eV. The spectra show only very weak shake-up satellites centered at approximately 789.5 and 804.5eV (Fig. 4), about 10eV from the main bands, as reported earlier [29]. This observation is consistent with X-ray absorption data (XANES, EXAFS), which suggest the presence of significant Co3O4 concentrations in these catalysts. At the surface the proportions of Co2+ and Co3+ are very similar to those observed in the bulk by XANES analysis and related to Co3O4 structure. Differently, for 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 sample the intense satellite structure [29,33] and high energy of the XPS Co 2p3/2 peaks (782.1eV) confirmed the predominance of Co2+ions, which were also detected by X-ray absorption spectroscopy. For calcined bimetallic catalysts, the XPS decomposition suggests higher proportions of Fe2+ at the surface compared with the bulk (Table 4 ). For 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3, the characterization results are indicative of higher concentration of Co2+ species. The EXAFS data suggest different cobalt coordination in this catalyst compared to Co3O4 phase. The observed phenomena could be explained assuming formation of Co–Fe spinel (e.g. CoFe2O4) in which Co is incorporated into the Fe3O4 phase after calcination. This observation is corroborated by the literature data [9,12,34,35]. In 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst, the fraction of mixed Co–Fe spinel can be smaller. From decomposition of Co 2p XPS spectrum, the fractions of Co3+ and Co2+ are respectively equal to 45 and 55% (Table 4) in 10Co/Al2O3. Note that these values are different from the fractions of Co3+ and Co2+ ions in the same catalyst obtained from XANES analysis (2/3 of Co3+ and 1/3 of Co2+). The depth of XPS analysis is about 7–10nm. XPS is usually presented as a surface sensitive technique, while XANES provides information both about bulk and surface compositions of the catalysts. The observed difference in Co3+/Co2+ ratio observed by XANES and XPS can be due to different composition of catalyst subsurface layer and catalyst bulk. This difference can be attributed to the higher fraction of Co2+ ions at the surface in interaction with the support leading to formation of Fe–Al mixed oxides. Although iron ions are mostly present as the Fe2O3 structure, the presence of significant amounts of Fe2+ ions was detected by XPS (Table 4) at the surface of calcined iron monometallic and bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts. Thus could be indicative of either iron species in interaction with the support or the presence of Fe3O4 species on the interface between the two phases. A strong interaction between iron oxides and alumina leading to formation of mixed oxides has been reported in previous publications [36,37]. It is known that n Co/n Al or n Fe/n Al ratio of atomic concentrations determined by XPS provides information about the sizes of metal oxide particles [5,22]. Indeed, higher concentration of metal detected by XPS suggests smaller sizes of oxide particles. The obtained XPS results confirm that in the monometallic catalysts, iron is better dispersed on alumina support than cobalt. This is consistent with smaller particle sizes measured by XRD (Table 1). Interestingly, Co3O4 particle sizes measured by XRD and XPS are in good agreement, even if the Scherrer equation used to calculate crystallite sizes from the width of XRD patterns could to some extent overestimate the crystallite sizes [38]. For iron monometallic catalyst, XRD patterns do not provide with sufficient accuracy the Fe2O3 particle size due to the significant peak broadening (Fig. 1). XPS data also suggest higher iron dispersion in bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts. Iron dispersion seems to be particularly important in 7.5Co2.5Fe/Al2O3 and 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts. In a more quantitative manner, cobalt and iron dispersions in the calcined bimetallic catalysts were evaluated from the n Co/n Al or n Fe/n Al ratios determined by XPS normalized by the theoretical atomic ratio corresponding to monolayer coverage of the support by cobalt or iron species (Table 3). It is noticeable that at the lowest cobalt content (2.5%), the XPS n Co/n Al atomic ratio at 0.03 is lower than the ratio corresponding to the monolayer (0.05). Higher cobalt dispersion was detected in the catalysts with lower cobalt contents (Table 3). Thus, addition of iron seems to increase cobalt dispersion. Indeed, 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 and 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts exhibit higher cobalt dispersion than the monometallic 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst. This result is in agreement with smaller cobalt crystallites in bimetallic catalysts calculated using Kerkof–Moulijn model (Table 1). Indeed, the size of Co3O4 crystallites calculated from XPS analysis decreases when cobalt content is lower (Table 1). Interestingly, addition of small amounts of cobalt to iron catalyst also enhances iron dispersion: 48% for 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 compared with 22% for 10Fe/Al2O3. Note however that bimetallic 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 and 7.5Co2.5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts have similar iron dispersion. 3.2 Catalyst reduction The TPR profiles of monometallic and bimetallic cobalt and iron catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The TPR curves of monometallic 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 5a) exhibit three groups of hydrogen consumption peaks: low, medium and high temperature peaks. In agreement with previous reports [8,20,40], the low temperature peaks between the room temperature and 603K were mainly attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO. The small shoulder at 453K seems to be related to the decomposition of residual un-decomposed nitrate species in hydrogen [41]. The second group of peaks situated between 603K and 1053K is mainly attributed to the reduction of CoO particles to metallic cobalt and cobalt species interacting strongly with the support, while the high temperature peaks (T >1053K) could probably be attributed to the reduction of cobalt aluminate compounds and/or very small cobalt oxide particles. The cobalt aluminate compounds can form via incorporation of Co2+ ions into the tetrahedral vacancies of the defect spinel structure of alumina during the reduction as shown by Moen et al. [42]. The TPR profile of 10Fe/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 5) is much more complex and exhibits a very broad unresolved peak situated between 473 and 873K. This peak with a maximum at 623K can possibly correspond to the different iron reduction steps [9]. Hydrogen consumption at higher temperatures (T >873K) could probably be attributed to formation of barely reducible Fe–Al spinels. These species could form via reaction of iron oxides with alumina. The TPR profiles obtained for bimetallic catalysts exhibit several overlapping peaks. The exact interpretation of the TPR signals seems even more difficult (Fig. 5). At low temperatures (around 493K), some TPR broad peak might be assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 species to CoO and to decomposition of residual nitrate species. At high temperatures (around 1073–1273K), a broad peak appears similarly to that present in the TPR profiles of the monometallic catalysts. This peak could be attributed to the reduction of small cobalt and/or iron oxide particles or aluminate compounds. Variation of catalyst magnetization during temperature ramping in pure hydrogen is shown in Fig. 6 . Note that only cobalt metallic particles have noticeable magnetization in 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst under these conditions [43]. Thus, an increase in magnetization directly indicates the growth of cobalt metallic phases in the catalyst. In agreement with TPR results, Co0 species were detected in 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst using in situ magnetic method at temperatures higher than 603K. For monometallic 10Fe/Al2O3 catalyst, a small increase in magnetization at temperatures from 603K to 683K and a sharp rise of magnetization at temperature higher than 683K could be respectively attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to ferrimagnetic magnetite (Fe3O4) and then to ferromagnetic Fe0 via FeO: Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO→Fe The magnetization curves obtained for 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 and 7.5Co2.5Fe/Al2O3 show that the reduction of cobalt and iron oxide species occurs at lower temperature (573K) than in the monometallic samples. For 5Co5Fe/Al2O3, the magnetization curve seems to be a superposition of the profiles of the monometallic samples (Fig. 6, curve b compared to curves a and c). Our conclusion about multi-step reduction of cobalt and iron species is consistent with previous TPR–EXAFS reports which were recently reviewed by Jacobs et al. [44]. Combined TPR-EXAFS is particularly helpful for interpretation of complex TPR profiles. Indeed, a number of EXAFS reports [26,45,46] suggest reduction of cobalt Co3O4 which proceed via intermediate formation of CoO. Using scanning transmission X-ray microscopy, de Smit et al. [47] showed the presence of intermediate Fe3O4 during reduction of Fe/Cu/K/Si catalysts. The oxidation state of cobalt and iron in the reduced catalysts was also investigated using XPS (Fig. 7 , Table 5 ). The catalysts were reduced in the XPS pretreatment chamber and transferred to the analysis chamber without any exposure to air. For 10Co/Al2O3 both cobalt metallic and oxidized Co2+ species were observed. The Co 2p3/2 peak at 779eV and the Co 2p1/2 peak at 794eV were characteristic of cobalt metal species [25]. The extent of reduction calculated from XPS data was about 29% in 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst (Table 5). The fraction of Co2+ was respectively 71%. The observed Co2+ species were assigned to the presence of residual CoO species and barely reducible cobalt aluminates. In the reduced monometallic 10Fe/Al2O3, both iron metallic and oxidized Fe2+ and Fe3+ species can be observed using XPS. The fraction of Fe0 was 7% which is smaller than the fraction of Co0 obtained after reduction of 10Co/Al2O3 (29%). This is consistent with the smaller size of iron crystallites and higher dispersion of iron species observed in the calcined supported catalyst. Moreover, more difficult reducibility of iron compared to cobalt has been already reported in the literature [48]. FeO was the most abundant iron species on the surface of the catalyst after reduction, indicating that the catalyst reduction results in FeO rather than in Fe0. This result can be due to the strong interaction between Fe and Al2O3 [36,37,49,50] which leads to the formation of non-stoichiometric hardly reducible FeAl spinels during calcination and possibly during the catalyst reduction. The Co2p and Fe2p XPS spectra of reduced bimetallic catalysts are also shown in Fig. 7. The higher extent of iron reduction is obtained for the bimetallic 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. This catalyst showed the presence of Co–Fe mixed oxide after calcination. Table 5 suggests that addition of cobalt to iron catalysts improves iron reduction. At the same time, the presence of added iron species (Table 5) makes cobalt reduction more difficult. This suggests that interaction of cobalt and iron species affects both cobalt and iron reducibilities. In particular, XPS of the reduced 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst indicates a larger concentration of Co2+ ions after the reduction. The observed modifications of cobalt and iron reducibilities are consistent with formation of hardly reducible mixed cobalt–iron species in the bimetallic catalysts. Catalyst reducibility in 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst was also investigated using in situ XRD using a synchrotron radiation source (λ =0.05nm, SNBL-ESRF, Grenoble, Fig. 8 ). During the reduction, the Co3O4 peak at 2θ =14.55° was observed up to 463K. At higher temperatures, the CoO and Co° XRD peaks appeared. The XRD peaks of CoO disappeared however after prolonged catalyst treatment in H2 at 658K. In the monometallic cobalt catalyst 10Co/Al2O3, in agreement with the literature, the peak characteristic of metallic cobalt was detected at 2θ =14.01° [20]. In 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 the XRD peak corresponding to metal species shifts to 14.3°. This shift could be probably assigned to the presence of CoFe alloy, which could result from the reduction of CoFe mixed oxide species. This observation is in agreement with the data of Duvenhage and Coville [51] who reported a FeCo alloy formation upon reduction of a 5Fe5Co/TiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic behavior The catalytic performance of cobalt and iron catalysts was measured in millifixed bed reactor (d int =2mm) at 513K, total pressure of 20bar and H2/CO ratio of 2 (Table 6 ). Under these conditions the catalysts exhibited only a slight initial decrease in the reaction rate. FT reaction rate and methane selectivity have been obtained at quasi steady state conditions obtained after 48h in time-on-stream (Fig. 9 ). The catalytic performance of the monometallic 10Co/Al2O3 catalyst was consistent with available literature data [7,8,52–54]. The reaction rate was much lower with 10Fe/Al2O3 compared with the value obtained for 10Co/Al2O3. In the bimetallic catalysts, higher fraction of iron results in lower catalytic activity. Interestingly, 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 and 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts containing high concentration of CoFe mixed compounds showed the lowest catalytic performance, even lower than the monometallic iron catalyst. The selectivity to long chain hydrocarbon is also affected by formation of mixed CoFe compounds. The C5+ selectivity was generally lower than in bimetallic catalysts, while the selectivity to olefins increased with higher iron concentration in the catalysts. Higher selectivity to methane over bimetallic Co–Fe system especially at high amount of Fe (30–40%) might be a result of very high Co dispersion in the presence of Fe. It was previously shown [55] that smaller cobalt metal particles might have high hydrogenation activity which could lead to high methane and low C5+ selectivities. 3.4 Active sites in bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Cobalt and iron based systems are most common catalyst for FT synthesis. In supported cobalt and iron based catalysts, the cobalt and iron structure significantly evolve during different catalyst preparation steps. Catalyst characterization data suggest the presence of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 in calcined monometallic cobalt and iron catalysts. Though Co3O4 and Fe2O3 phases remain dominant in the bimetallic catalysts, these catalysts also show higher than expected concentrations of Co2+ and some amounts of Fe2+ ions which can originate from cobalt and iron species interacting with alumina support. The bimetallic calcined catalysts exhibit the presence of mixed cobalt iron oxides (e.g. Co x Fe1−x Fe2O4). The concentration of mixed oxides seems to be more significant in 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3. In the alumina supported monometallic catalyst, Co3O4 particles of 11nm were detected by both XRD and XPS, while iron dispersion is much more important in monometallic 10Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. Metal dispersion is also significantly affected by the presence of cobalt and iron in bimetallic catalysts. Our estimation using Kerkof–Moulijn model [22] suggests that the sizes of cobalt oxide crystallites in the calcined catalysts were between 7 and 17nm, while the apparent size of iron oxide is much smaller (2–6nm). Addition of cobalt to iron catalysts seems to slightly enhance the iron dispersion (Table 3). Hydrogen treatment results in the reduction of cobalt and iron oxides to metallic species via formation of intermediate species. The cobalt reduction seems to proceed much easier than of iron species. The in situ magnetic measurements suggest that addition of cobalt to iron catalysts improves to some extent reduction of iron species, while the presence of iron hinders cobalt reduction (Fig. 6). These results are consistent with XPS data obtained on the catalysts pre-reduced in the XPS pretreatment chamber and transferred to analysis without exposure to air. The fraction of metallic cobalt drops from 29% in the monometallic cobalt catalyst to 11% in the bimetallic catalysts, while fraction of iron metallic species increases from 7% in monometallic iron catalyst to 23% in the bimetallic catalysts (Table 5). Cobalt and iron catalysts exhibit rather different catalytic performance in FT synthesis. Higher FT reaction rate is observed on cobalt monometallic catalyst compared to iron counterpart. As previously discussed by Davis [56], a direct comparison of the activity of cobalt and iron catalysts is a difficult task. The catalytic activity of cobalt catalysts is usually related to the number of available cobalt surface sites. It is usually expected that cobalt surface sites have the same intrinsic activity (turnover frequency) with some exception for cobalt particle smaller than 6–8nm. Those smaller cobalt particles may exhibit lower turnover frequencies and higher methane selectivity [55]. The situation is much more complex with iron catalysts which may contain several active sites for FT reaction such iron carbides and metallic iron. Several publications suggest [56] that even iron oxides (e.g. Fe3O4) could be active in carbon monoxide hydrogenation. In addition, the concentration of different iron species could be a function of the catalyst pretreatment and reaction operating conditions (total pressure, syngas composition, temperature, etc.). There is a general consensus however [57] that the concentration of iron carbides in iron catalysts increases with the reaction temperature. Thus, mostly metallic iron could provide reactions sites for low temperature FT synthesis, while high temperature FT synthesis would involve to a larger extent iron carbide species. In addition, the catalytic activity could be a function of carbon monoxide conversion with cobalt catalysts being more active than iron counterparts at higher conversion levels [58]. To identify the cobalt and iron phases present during FT reaction, the 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst has been investigated using in situ synchrotron-based XRD. The experiment was first conducted at 20bar with syngas and H2/CO ratio of 2 at 508K for 145min, GHSV=25,000cm3 g−1 h−1. Then the catalysts was treated under the conditions more favorable to carbidization (H2/CO=1 ratio, P =20bar, T =220°C). The GHSV was reduced to 17,500cm3 h−1 g−1. Interestingly, no evolution of the XRD profiles was observed either in syngas with H2/CO=2 or 1 (Fig. 10 ). This suggests an enhanced stability of the bimetallic CoFe catalysts to sintering. Previous in situ measurements were indicative of considerable versatility of alumina supported cobalt catalysts during Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [20]. For monometallic cobalt catalyst, sintering occurred at the first hours of the reaction. No modification of the intensity of XRD peaks assigned to CoFe alloys was either observed under these conditions. This also suggests relative stability bimetallic CoFe catalysts to carbidization. Previously Li et al. [59] observed using in situ EXAFS gradual carbidization of iron oxides at 250°C after several hours of the exposure to flowing syngas with H2/CO=2. Our data suggest that at the same total metal content, cobalt catalysts are more active than iron catalysts. This observation is also consistent with the data of Botes et al. [57] which were also indicative of higher activity of cobalt catalysts in FT synthesis calculated on a weight basis. Note however that this comparison is only relevant to the bulk catalytic activity calculated per gram of the catalyst. The catalysts phase composition in cobalt and iron catalysts could be very different after activation (Table 5) and different active species in iron catalysts could have rather different intrinsic catalytic activities. The bimetallic cobalt iron catalysts show intermediate or even lower catalytic activities compared to cobalt and iron monometallic catalysts (Table 6). Characterization data suggest that interaction between cobalt and iron species in bimetallic catalysts results in a major modification of the catalytic properties. The bimetallic catalysts in addition to cobalt and iron metallic phase also, contain CoFe mixed species (alloys in the reduced catalysts and oxides in calcined counterparts). Surprisingly, the 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst which presumably contains a higher fraction of these mixed species has shown a very low catalyst activity. Lower activity of 2.5Co7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst could be possibly attributed to more difficult reduction of active cobalt phase in the presence of iron and to the particular structure of cobalt–iron metallic particles in the bimetallic catalysts. Indeed, the surface energy of metallic iron is somewhat smaller than that of cobalt [60,61]. To minimize the total energy of bimetal nanoparticles, a lower surface energy of iron would lead to the enrichment of the external surface of bimetallic nanoparticles with less catalytically active iron species and would result in a lower catalytic performance. Thus, it can be suggested that spontaneous formation of bimetallic particles would leads to the enrichment of the external surface with less reactive iron component and to the drop in catalytic activity. It can be expected therefore that because of the enrichment of the external surface with iron bimetallic cobalt–iron particles would have catalytic performance similar to iron rather than to cobalt metal particles. The activity of cobalt–iron bimetallic catalysts could be improved however by specific synthetic methods which would involve selective design of “core–shell catalysts” with higher concentration of more active cobalt species on the external surface of cobalt–iron bimetallic particles [62]. Another interesting observation is lower C5+ selectivity observed on bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts. The bimetallic catalysts seem to produce more lighter hydrocarbons and olefins than monometallic counterparts (Table 6). For example at carbon monoxide conversion of 13–14%, the C5+ selectivity was 41% over 5Co5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst compared to 72% observed on 10Fe/Al2O3 sample. Lower C5+ selectivity could be at least partially attributed to the presence of smaller cobalt metal particles which have higher hydrogenation activity in FT synthesis [55]. In addition, the presence of iron results in some increase in CO2 production. Cobalt species have very low activity in water–gas shift reaction. On iron and bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts CO2 seems to be produced via the water gas shift reaction catalyzed by iron species: CO+H2O=CO2 +H2 Previously, Lögdberg et al. [9] assigned lower C5+ selectivity to higher H2/CO ratio which can be due to water gas shift reaction. Note however that CO2 selectivity (7%) was not very important under the conditions used in this work and is not likely to be the only reason of lower C5+ selectivity on bimetallic catalysts. Lower chain growth probability often observed on unpromoted iron active sites could also contribute to lower C5+ selectivity on iron containing catalysts [63]. It should be also noted that the bimetallic cobalt iron catalysts contain significant amounts of unreduced cobalt and iron oxides. The acidity of the unreduced metal oxides could also affect the chain growth probability. It would lead to the formation of lighter hydrocarbons and can increase olefin production. 4 Conclusion A combination of characterization techniques allowed obtaining qualitative and quantitative information about the structure of iron–cobalt bimetallic catalysts supported on alumina support for FT reaction. The results have clearly shown considerable differences in the nature of oxide and reduced phases in bimetallic cobalt–iron catalysts as a function of Co/Fe ratio. Iron forms much more dispersed species in monometallic catalysts than cobalt. Iron reduction seems to be much difficult that of cobalt. Alumina supported monometallic iron catalyst exhibited much lower FT reaction rate calculated on the catalyst weight basis than the cobalt counterpart. Interaction of cobalt and iron in bimetallic catalysts leads to much different cobalt dispersion and reducibility. Cobalt reducibility is more difficult in the presence of iron, while the presence of cobalt improves iron reducibility. Characterization data suggest formation of cobalt–iron mixed species in both calcined and reduced catalysts. The bimetallic catalysts have intermediate catalytic performance compared to cobalt or iron counterparts. Formation of bimetallic cobalt iron particles leads to higher olefin selectivity but lower carbon monoxide conversion rate. Acknowledgements The authors thank A.-S. Mamede, M. Trentesaux, P. coredata.dc:description: This paper focuses on the identification of cobalt and iron species in bimetallic alumina supported catalysts and their role in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The catalysts are prepared via aqueous coimpregnation of alumina with solutions of cobalt and iron nitrates followed by calcination in air and reduction in hydrogen. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of cobalt and iron phases were performed using XANES/EXAFS, XRD, TPR, XPS and magnetic method. The results show that Co3O4 and Fe2O3 are the major phases in the calcined monometallic cobalt and iron catalysts, while the bimetallic catalysts also exhibited the presence of mixed Co–Fe oxides. Reduction of these Co–Fe oxides leads to cobalt–iron bimetallic particles. The Fischer–Tropsch reaction rate increases with cobalt content in bimetallic catalysts. Formation of mixed cobalt–iron species increases selectivity to lighter olefins compared to cobalt monometallic catalyst but leads to lower Fischer–Tropsch reaction rates.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt and iron species in alumina supported bimetallic catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch reaction
